subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: Hi Moira, Thanks for your personal experiences. It would be nice to know at length at some future date the history of QS users. A while back there was talk
messageBody:
Hi Moira,

Thanks for your personal experiences. It would be nice to know at length
at some future date the history of QS users. A while back there was talk
about a newsletter. An article talking about various correspondence
groups, which might also talk about dialects, would be very interesting.

Yes, the discussion has gotten very technical, but I think a lot of will
come from it. It has expanded my understanding of language greatly, and
even more so has helped me clarify my understanding of what QS is. But
though the discussion is technical, the explanation for most users
doesn't have to be. In fact, the clearest simplest explanations come
from those with a very thorough, deep understanding.

You seem to advocate a somewhat standard way of using QS. Read seems to
believe that is how QS should be used. From your excerpt, he states that
standardization saves "thought" and makes it easier for everyone to
read. (I hope I understand this quote right.) Though earlier I argued
that QS should allow users to express their dialects, such a use would
ultimately make QS less practical.

Regarding your inability to post the documents to the Yahoo group, I
think that is a major shortcoming of Yahoo groups in general. But not
only does it limit the file size, it doesn't really provide for a good
way to store files. I have started a project at sourceforge, an open
source site that hosts many very professional, high end projects such as
Open Office. I hope to make it a friendly place to find articles and
other fiction written in QS, so you could always post your material there.

Paul

Hi Moira,

Thanks for your personal experiences. It would be nice to know at length
at some future date the history of QS users. A while back there was talk
about a newsletter. An article talking about various correspondence
groups, which might also talk about dialects, would be very interesting.

Yes, the discussion has gotten very technical, but I think a lot of will
come from it. It has expanded my understanding of language greatly, and 
even more so has helped me clarify my understanding of what QS is. But 
though the discussion is technical, the explanation for most users

from those with a very thorough, deep understanding.

You seem to advocate a somewhat standard way of using QS. Read seems to

standardization saves "thought" and makes it easier for everyone to 
read. (I hope I understand this quote right.) Though earlier I argued

Regarding your inability to post the documents to the Yahoo group, I
